title: Soho House wants your money, not your company
text:
One thing to start: EG Group, the highly leveraged petrol stations business whose billionaire owners have bought the UK supermarket chain Asda, is planning to raise an extra $1.8bn in the next stage of the group's debt-fuelled acquisition spree. More here from DD's Kaye Wiggins and Rob Smith.

Welcome to Due Diligence, your briefing on dealmaking, private equity and corporate finance from the Financial Times. Want to receive DD in your inbox? Sign up here. Get in touch with us anytime: Due.Diligence@ft.com.

Soho House considers opening its doors to the public markets

Hopes of booming demand for holidays, meals or just anything to get out of the house has whipped up sentiment for travel and leisure stocks — so much so that even Soho House is considering a listing.

The chichi private members' club for moneyed creative types and the celebrity likes of Prince Harry and Kate Moss is planning to float on the New York Stock Exchange as soon as next month with hopes of a $3bn valuation, insiders told the FT's Alice Hancock and DD's Robert Smith.

It is the second bite at a listing for the London-based hospitality group, which hired JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs in 2018 to draw up plans for an IPO before founder Nick Jones and even wealthier fellow owners, the US billionaire Ron Burkle and hospitality tycoon Richard Caring, decided they were happy with the set-up — and had enough cash from a £275m debt refinancing to do without.

But the pandemic has not been kind to the group, which derives almost half of its revenues from food and drinks at its 27 clubs, 20 restaurants and 16 spas — most of which are currently closed.

It has retained more than 90 per cent of its members, miraculously, even with clubs closed but has been forced to cut 1,000 of its 8,000 staff.

Dig deeper and Soho House's capital structure also offers an insight into the excesses of the private credit industry.

In 2015 the company tried and failed to tap the high-yield bond market for £200m. This story from DD's Rob Smith — in his previous life as a Reuters bond market reporter — has plenty of amusing quotes from snooty fund managers, griping about the fact that finance professionals have traditionally been barred from the members' club.

“They say that we're not cool enough to join their club, but they're perfectly willing to take our money when they need it!” said one.

(Since that story, Soho House has launched The Ned, its outpost in the City that shrewdly allows London finance professionals behind the velvet rope.)

But where traditional bond fund managers feared to tread, the private credit industry had no such qualms: Permira Debt Managers, the credit arm of the private equity house, provided a £350m loan to Soho House in 2017, describing the debt deal as its “largest-ever direct lending investment” at the time.

How did that loan perform during a pandemic that shuttered the company's clubs? Well, recently filed accounts don't paint a pretty picture: they reveal that the company stopped making interest payments on its loan in cash last year, instead choosing to use a “payment in kind” option. This allows companies with limited cash flow to pay lenders with more debt instead. Ouch.

PDM, which has a lot of exposure to UK travel and leisure companies, is likely hoping that the mooted IPO goes without a hitch. 

Coinbase: to the moon 🚀🚀🚀

It's not every day that the head of a soon-to-be-public company tells investors he plans to run the business at break even — after making more than $300m in profits the year before.

But that is the position of Brian Armstrong, chief executive of the cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase, which unveiled its investment prospectus on Thursday.

“We may earn a profit when revenues are high, and we may lose money when revenues are low, but our goal is to roughly operate the company at break-even, smoothed out over time, for the time being,” Armstrong wrote to investors. 

DD would like to know how much Coinbase paid its lawyers at Fenwick to help craft that pithy statement. It seems they had plenty to work on with this prospectus, which contained some of the more interesting risk factors we've seen in a while.

First, there's the elephant in the room: Coinbase's revenues are “substantially dependent” on the price of cryptocurrencies and trading volumes on the exchange. 

Second, there are the regulatory matters, including an “investigative subpoena for documents and information about certain of our customer programmes and operations” issued by the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

Last but not least, Coinbase said the unveiling of Satoshi Nakamoto, the pseudonymous inventor of bitcoin, could adversely affect the market for bitcoin and ethereum and, thus, its business.

It's hard to blame Armstrong for acting so cautious in this market environment when everything from dogecoin to pre-merger blank cheque companies seems to be going up and to the right.

Coinbase chose a direct listing rather than a traditional initial public offering, meaning it won't raise any capital. Instead, it will rely on trades in private markets to help set its price. 

If this month's trades are any indication, that means Coinbase could be a $100bn company when it lists. That's a lofty mark to live up to for any new public company head.

Jay-Z: ‘I'm not a businessman, I'm a business, man!'

When Jay-Z met up with Warren Buffett at Omaha's Hollywood Diner 11 years ago, the two sipped on strawberry milkshakes and talked business with Steve Forbes.

Perhaps the Oracle of Omaha saw a glimpse into his future that day — not as just an artist and successful businessman but as a master dealmaker.

Jay-Z began this week (figuratively) shaking hands with LVMH boss Bernard Arnault in a deal to expand his Armand de Brignac champagne (coined in his raps as “that Ace of Spades”) globally; the very next day, Oatly, the Swedish vegan-milk group he backed along with Blackstone and Oprah Winfrey, took its first step towards a $10bn IPO.

If it wasn't for the pandemic, he'd likely be in Paris living out the lyrics he wrote with Kanye West for their joint 2011 album Watch The Throne, partying in the five-star Le Meurice hotel “for like six days”, Ace spouting into the air.

And what would a star dealmaker be without a few Spac deals under his belt? Jay has added to his CV the title of “chief visionary officer” of a Spac backed by Roc Nation, the music and spot talent agency he heads, which acquired two cannabis groups in November.

To Jay-Z fans, the successful dealmaking spree comes as no surprise. In the rapper's own words since circa 2001: “Put me anywhere on God's green Earth, I triple my worth.”

Job moves

  • TIAA has hired Thasunda Brown Duckett, one of the leaders of JPMorgan's consumer bank Chase, to become chief executive at the $1.3tn investment manager. Read more here.

  • Hubert Barth, the head of longstanding Wirecard auditor EY Germany, is expected to step down from the role, insiders told the FT's Olaf Storbeck.

  • Bessemer Venture Partners is adding five new partners, including Jeff Blackburn, who joins from Amazon, alongside the promotion of existing Bessemer investors Mary D'Onofrio, Mike Droesch, Tess Hatch and Andrew Hedin.

  • Bank of America has promoted Anthony Knox to co-head of investment banking for South Africa alongside Justin Bothner. He was previously a managing director in the same department and will continue to be based in Johannesburg.

Smart reads

Sneakernomics The cut-throat streetwear resale market has transformed Air Jordans and Yeezys into a full-blown asset class. Only unlike the regulated markets, sneakerheads come equipped with armies of bots to boost their spending power. (Bloomberg)

Desert drag race Lucid, the electric vehicle start-up backed by Saudi Arabia, has teamed up with a Spac to give Elon Musk a run for his money. But its cars have a lot of ground to cover to stand a chance at outpacing Tesla, or generating any revenue. (FT)

Out with the old . . . McKinsey global managing partner Kevin Sneader was voted out of the embattled consultancy over his handling of a string of reputational crises laid before him when he entered the top job. Now, the firm grapples with how to transform its culture. (FT)

KPMG UK to split roles of chair and chief executive (FT)

AT&T unloads DirecTV stake to TPG and spins off pay-TV units (FT) 

Moderna expects $18.4bn from Covid vaccine deals this year (FT)

Ousted Petrobras chief hits back at Bolsonaro (FT) 

Airbnb points to its ‘resilience' as business begins to bounce back (FT) 

Suning plans $2.5bn stake sale in bid to strengthen finances (FT)
